courseDescription: 16-week intensive program to become a job-ready full-stack developer

weeks.title: Week 0: Onboarding & Foundations
weeks.description: Get started with development tools, set up your environment, learn computational thinking, and complete your first coding exercises

sections.title: Day 1: Course Overview & Learning Philosophy
sections.description: Understanding the course structure and developing effective learning strategies

content.content: Welcome to Week 0 of your full-stack engineering journey! This week is designed to set you up for success in the 16-week program ahead. You'll establish your development environment, learn the foundational tools every developer uses, and complete your first coding exercises.

Think of this week as your launch pad. By the end of Week 0, you'll have everything configured, you'll understand how professional developers work, and you'll have written your first lines of code in multiple programming languages.

items: Duration: 7 Days (Day 1-7)
Time Commitment: 12-15 hours total
Difficulty Level: Beginner-Friendly
Prerequisites: None! Just bring curiosity and commitment

content.content: By the end of Week 0, you will be able to:

items: Explain what full-stack development is and the career opportunities it offers
Navigate your computer using the command line interface
Use Git for version control and collaborate using GitHub
Write and execute basic programs in HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and Python
Apply computational thinking to break down problems systematically
Set up a professional development environment used by engineers worldwide
Growth mindset: You can learn anything with practice
Active learning: Hands-on coding beats passive watching
The debugging mindset: Errors are learning opportunities
Spaced repetition: Review concepts regularly
Community learning: Help others to reinforce your understanding

questions.question: What is a growth mindset?
options: Believing your abilities are fixed and cannot change
Believing you can develop your abilities through practice and effort
Only focusing on what you're naturally good at
questions.explanation: A growth mindset means believing that your abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work. This view creates a love of learning and resilience essential for great accomplishment.

questions.question: Which learning approach is most effective for coding?
questions.explanation: Active learning through hands-on coding is the most effective way to learn programming. Building real projects helps you understand concepts deeply and develop problem-solving skills.

questions.question: When you encounter an error in your code, what should you do?
options: Give up and move to something easier
Copy and paste code without understanding it
View it as a learning opportunity and debug systematically
Ask someone else to fix it for you immediately
questions.explanation: Errors are valuable learning opportunities. Debugging systematically teaches you how to read error messages, understand what went wrong, and develop problem-solving skills that are crucial for developers.

sections.title: Lesson 1: What is Full-Stack Development?
sections.description: 90 minutes - Understanding the complete web development landscape

content.content: Full-stack development refers to building both the frontend (what users see) and backend (server and database) of web applications. As a full-stack developer, you'll understand the complete technology stack and how all the pieces fit together.

items: Define full-stack development and its components
Understand the difference between frontend, backend, and databases
Identify career paths and job opportunities for developers
Recognize the technologies you'll learn throughout the course

content.title: What is Full Stack Development? - Complete Overview (15 min)
content.description: Comprehensive introduction covering frontend, backend, databases, and career paths. This video explains how all components work together in modern web applications.

content.content: Frontend Development: The 'client-side' - everything users see and interact with in their browser. Technologies: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React.
Backend Development: The 'server-side' - handles business logic, authentication, and data processing. Technologies: Node.js, Express, Python, APIs.
Database: Where data is stored and retrieved. Technologies: PostgreSQL, MongoDB, MySQL.
Full-Stack Developer: A developer who can work on both frontend and backend, understanding how all pieces connect together.

items: Frontend: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React
Backend: Node.js, Express.js
Database: PostgreSQL
Tools: Git, GitHub, VS Code, Command Line
Deployment: Cloud platforms and hosting

questions.question: What does the frontend of a web application refer to?
options: The database where data is stored
Everything the user sees and interacts with in their browser
The code that runs on the server
questions.explanation: The frontend (client-side) is everything users see and interact with in their web browser, including the visual design, layout, and interactive elements.

questions.question: Which of these is a backend technology?
questions.explanation: Node.js and Express are backend technologies that run on the server to handle business logic, authentication, and data processing.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a database in web applications?
options: To store and retrieve data persistently
questions.explanation: Databases store and retrieve data persistently, allowing applications to save user information, posts, transactions, and any other data that needs to be preserved.

questions.question: What does a full-stack developer do?
options: Works on both frontend and backend
questions.explanation: Full-stack developers work on both the frontend (what users see) and backend (server logic and databases), understanding how all parts of an application work together.

sections.title: Lesson 3: Introduction to the Command Line
sections.description: 90 minutes - Terminal basics and hands-on practice

content.content: The command line (also called terminal or shell) is how developers interact with their computer at a fundamental level. While it may seem intimidating at first, it's an essential skill that will make you much more efficient.

items: Much faster than clicking through folders
Required for using Git, npm, and deployment tools
Automate repetitive tasks with scripts
Access to powerful system utilities
Essential for server management and DevOps

content.title: Command Line Crash Course - Beginner Friendly (25 min)
content.description: Complete introduction to terminal commands and navigation for Windows, Mac, and Linux users.

content.code:
# pwd - Print Working Directory (where am I?)
pwd

# ls - List files and folders (what's here?)
ls
ls -la  # List all files including hidden ones

# cd - Change Directory (move around)
cd Documents        # Go into Documents folder
cd ..              # Go up one level
cd ~               # Go to home directory
cd /               # Go to root directory

# mkdir - Make new directory
mkdir my-project
mkdir -p projects/week0/code  # Create nested folders

# touch - Create new file (Mac/Linux)
touch index.html
touch style.css script.js

# On Windows, use:
echo. > index.html

# cp - Copy files
cp file.txt backup.txt
cp -r folder/ backup-folder/  # Copy entire folder

# mv - Move or rename files
mv old-name.txt new-name.txt
mv file.txt ../other-folder/

# rm - Remove files (CAREFUL!)
rm file.txt
rm -rf folder/  # Remove folder and contents (DANGEROUS!)

# cat - Display file contents
cat README.md

# code - Open in VS Code
code .              # Open current folder
code index.html     # Open specific file

# clear - Clear the terminal screen
clear
# Or use: Ctrl+L (Mac/Linux) or cls (Windows)

content.content: Complete this hands-on exercise to practice your new command line skills:

items: Open your terminal application
Navigate to your Desktop using cd
Create a folder called 'week0-practice'
Navigate into that folder
Create three files: hello.txt, notes.md, and script.js
Create a subfolder called 'backup'
Copy hello.txt into the backup folder
List all files to verify your work
Open the entire folder in VS Code using 'code .'
Use Tab to autocomplete file/folder names
Use up/down arrow keys to cycle through previous commands
Use Ctrl+C to cancel a running command
Use Ctrl+R to search command history
Type 'man <command>' to see the manual (Mac/Linux)

questions.question: Which command shows your current directory location?
questions.explanation: pwd (Print Working Directory) shows your current location in the file system. It's useful to know where you are before running other commands.

questions.question: How do you create a new directory named 'projects'?
questions.explanation: mkdir (make directory) creates a new folder. Example: 'mkdir projects' creates a folder named 'projects' in your current directory.

questions.question: What does 'cd ..' do?
questions.explanation: 'cd ..' moves you up one level in the directory hierarchy. The '..' represents the parent directory.

questions.question: Which command is DANGEROUS and can delete files permanently?
questions.explanation: 'rm -rf' recursively deletes files and folders without confirmation. Always double-check what you're deleting! Files deleted with rm cannot be recovered from the trash.

sections.title: Lesson 4: Version Control with Git Basics
sections.description: 120 minutes - Git fundamentals and GitHub setup

content.content: Git is version control software that tracks changes to your code over time. GitHub is a website where you can store your code online and collaborate with others. Every professional developer uses these tools daily.

items: Track every change you make to your code
Collaborate with other developers on the same project
Revert to previous versions if something breaks
Create branches to experiment without breaking your main code
Required by employers - Git is an industry standard

content.title: Git and GitHub for Beginners - Crash Course (70 min)
content.description: Comprehensive tutorial covering repositories, commits, branches, pull requests, and real-world workflows. This is the definitive starting point for Git beginners.

content.content: Repository (Repo): A folder that Git is tracking - contains all your files and their complete history.
Commit: A snapshot of your code at a specific point in time. Like saving a game checkpoint that you can return to later.
Remote: A copy of your repository hosted online (usually on GitHub). Allows collaboration, backup, and portfolio showcase.
Branch: A separate line of development. The main branch is usually called 'main' or 'master'. You can create feature branches to work on new features without affecting the main code.

content.code:
# Configure Git (do this once)
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

# Initialize a new Git repository
git init

# Check which files have changed
git status

# Stage all changes for commit
git add .
# Or stage specific file:
git add index.html

# Create a commit with a message
git commit -m "Add homepage structure"

# Connect to GitHub repository
git remote add origin https://github.com/username/repo.git 

# Push commits to GitHub
git push origin main
# First time: git push -u origin main

# Pull changes from GitHub
git pull origin main

# View commit history
git log
git log --oneline  # Compact view

items: Make changes to your files in VS Code
Check status with 'git status' (see what changed)
Stage changes with 'git add .' (prepare to commit)
Commit with 'git commit -m "descriptive message"' (save snapshot)
Push to GitHub with 'git push' (upload to remote)

content.content: Good commit messages are short, descriptive, and start with a verb:

items: ‚úÖ GOOD: "Add login form validation"
‚úÖ GOOD: "Fix navigation menu on mobile"
‚úÖ GOOD: "Update README with installation steps"
‚ùå BAD: "updates"
‚ùå BAD: "fixed stuff"
‚ùå BAD: "asdfasdf"

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'git add .'?
options: Stages all changes to be committed
questions.explanation: 'git add .' stages all changed files, preparing them to be included in the next commit. The '.' means 'all files in current directory'.

questions.question: What does 'git commit' do?
options: Creates a snapshot of staged changes with a message
questions.explanation: 'git commit' creates a snapshot (checkpoint) of your staged changes. It saves the current state of your code with a descriptive message explaining what changed.

questions.question: What is the difference between Git and GitHub?
options: Git is the version control system, GitHub is a hosting service for Git repositories
Git is online, GitHub is offline
questions.explanation: Git is the version control software that runs on your computer. GitHub is a website that hosts Git repositories online, enabling collaboration and portfolio showcase.

questions.question: Which commit message follows best practices?
questions.explanation: Good commit messages are clear, descriptive, and start with a verb. 'Add user authentication feature' tells exactly what was changed and why.

sections.title: Lesson 5: Your First Code - Hello World
sections.description: 90 minutes - Writing your first programs in multiple languages

content.text: Your First Code: Hello World in Multiple Languages

content.content: The 'Hello World' program is a programming tradition. It's the simplest program you can write - just displays 'Hello World' on the screen. Let's write it in HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and Python!

items: Create an HTML file that displays your name and favorite hobby

sections.title: Final Quiz: Week 0 Comprehensive Assessment
sections.description: Test your understanding of all Week 0 concepts

content.content: This quiz covers all topics from Week 0. You have 30 minutes and 2 attempts. Take your time and review the lessons if needed before starting!

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of using Git for version control?
options: It makes your code run faster
It tracks changes and lets you revert to previous versions
It automatically fixes bugs in your code
It converts your code to different programming languages
questions.explanation: Git tracks every change you make to your code, allowing you to see the history, compare versions, and revert to previous states if something breaks.

questions.question: Which command creates a new directory named 'project'?
questions.explanation: 'mkdir' stands for 'make directory' and is used to create new folders from the command line.

questions.question: In full-stack development, what does the backend handle?
questions.explanation: The backend handles server-side logic including business rules, database operations, authentication, API endpoints, and data processing.

questions.question: What file extension do CSS files use?
questions.explanation: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) files use the .css extension. Example: style.css, main.css

questions.question: What does 'git push' do?
options: Uploads your commits to a remote repository (like GitHub)
questions.explanation: 'git push' uploads your local commits to a remote repository, making your changes available online and to collaborators.

questions.question: Which VS Code extension provides a live preview of your HTML?
questions.explanation: Live Server launches a local development server with live reload, automatically refreshing your browser when you save changes to your HTML, CSS, or JavaScript files.

questions.question: What does HTML stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. It's the standard markup language for creating web pages and defines the structure and content.

questions.question: What is a repository in Git?
options: A folder that Git tracks, containing files and their history
questions.explanation: A repository (repo) is a folder that Git tracks. It contains all your project files plus the complete history of changes made to those files.

questions.question: Which technology is used for styling web pages?
questions.explanation: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is used to style web pages, controlling colors, fonts, layouts, spacing, and visual presentation.

questions.question: What does 'pwd' display in the terminal?
options: A list of files in a directory
questions.explanation: 'pwd' stands for 'Print Working Directory' and displays the full path of your current location in the file system.

content.content: After completing this quiz, you're done with Week 0! Great job on completing the foundation week. You're now ready to start building real web applications in Week 1!
